lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Cold Start Problem and Atomic Networks.

disappointment_summary: Roomi usually works well enough to produce intros, but its experience is consistently mediocre at the moments where network effects should feel strongest: proving hyperlocal liquidity before signup, reducing trust friction before commitment, and compounding quality after move-in. The product delivers activity, not confidence, so users repeatedly do manual screening and off-platform coordination; this keeps many city-neighborhood-time-window atomic networks in a fragile state where they can match people once, but fail to build durable, self-reinforcing trust loops.

disappointments.title: City-Wide Promise, Block-Level Thinness
disappointments.what_happens_now: The app is positioned as fast roommate matching in a big city, but new users are not shown pre-signup neighborhood-level depth (for their budget and move-in window), so they discover thin pockets only after onboarding and swiping.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Search still returns profiles and listings, so the core function appears to work even when local relevance density is low.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Users interpret low early match quality as market weakness and disengage before reaching a first success; this is classic cold-start perception failure where confidence drops before the atomic network can tip.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, Cold Start theory and local network density)
evidence.observation: Networked products only feel useful when enough relevant participants are present in the same network slice.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Without visible proof of local density, users assume they are below threshold and exit early.

evidence.source: Roomi competitor UX observation from Layer 0 discovery
evidence.observation: Discovery emphasizes speed and major-city activity rather than precise submarket liquidity.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Top-of-funnel promise overstates utility for thin neighborhood-time segments.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: if users saw real neighborhood-time liquidity before signup, it would feel unexpectedly premium in a category where vague scale claims are normal.

disappointments.title: Filters Without Matchability Forecast
disappointments.what_happens_now: Users apply budget, location, and timing filters, then manually infer whether results are actually contactable and likely to respond; there is no clear forecast of response probability or active depth by filter combination.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Filtering and browsing function correctly, so nothing technically fails.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: People spend cognitive effort testing combinations and second-guessing whether poor results mean bad filters or weak supply, creating decision fatigue that lowers session persistence.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, value depends on the right people being present)
evidence.observation: Network value comes from relevant participants, not gross participant count.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Search UX should expose relevance density and expected interaction, not only list volume.

evidence.source: Roomi competitor UX observation from Layer 0 search
evidence.observation: Search is fast and broad but quality and freshness vary by submarket.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Users absorb volatility as personal effort instead of product guidance.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: a simple 'likely to match in 48h' signal would surprise users because roommate search tools usually make them do this math manually.

disappointments.title: Trust Stops at Surface-Level Profiles
disappointments.what_happens_now: During listing/profile review, users mostly compare photos, bios, and sparse metadata, but cannot quickly assess reliability depth (verification quality, consistency, past follow-through, ghosting risk).
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Profiles are viewable and contact can proceed, so the workflow is complete from a functional standpoint.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: At high-stakes co-living decisions, ambiguity triggers risk aversion; users over-index on weak proxies and either delay outreach or move conversations off-platform for confidence checks.

evidence.observation: Strong networked outcomes require robust product mechanics around connections, not just more connections.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Trust scaffolding is part of product quality that unlocks network value.

evidence.source: Public review pattern on roommate platforms
evidence.observation: Users frequently report scam concern and inconsistent listing quality.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Weak trust signals lower effective liquidity by making many nominal options feel unusable.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: deeper trust density signals at evaluation time would feel unusually reassuring in a category where users expect to self-audit strangers.

disappointments.title: Match Created, Commitment Unstructured
disappointments.what_happens_now: After initial mutual interest, users rely on ad hoc chat to negotiate terms (dates, deposits, house rules, responsibilities), and final commitment often shifts off-platform with no standardized offer-to-agreement flow.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: People can still exchange messages and make deals, so the platform appears to fulfill its matching role.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: The highest-anxiety moment lacks structure, so users fear misunderstanding and opportunism; this weakens conversion and prevents repeatable trust loops that strengthen atomic networks.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Atomic Networks chapter, product mechanics around interactions)
evidence.observation: Network growth is durable when interactions are converted into reliable, repeatable outcomes.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Unstructured commitment leaks value off-platform and reduces defensibility.

evidence.source: Roomi competitor UX observation from Layer 0 booking_proposal
evidence.observation: Conversation is supported, but formalized offer and acceptance mechanics are weak.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Conversion quality varies user-by-user instead of being productized.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: a structured roommate agreement flow would feel unexpectedly excellent because users currently expect to improvise a high-risk negotiation.

disappointments.title: Ghosting Is Normalized by Generic Messaging
disappointments.what_happens_now: In-app chat works as a basic thread, but there are few built-in prompts, milestones, or response expectations to keep first conversations progressing during the critical first 24-48 hours.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Messages send and deliver; users can communicate if they choose to.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Silence is interpreted as rejection or risk, which reduces willingness to invest in additional outreach and stalls the 'magic moment' where bilateral activity confirms network value.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, engagement depends on active interactions)
evidence.observation: Networks retain users when interactions are timely and meaningful.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Messaging quality is not just utility; it is the trigger for perceived network utility.

evidence.observation: Response latency strongly predicts conversion to real-world outcomes.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Default chat without orchestration tolerates avoidable ghosting.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: guided first-contact messaging that measurably cuts ghosting would delight because users have learned to expect dead-air as normal.

disappointments.title: Move-In Becomes Off-Platform Amnesia
disappointments.what_happens_now: Once people move in, Roomi contributes little to shared-living operations (rules alignment, issue logging, routine coordination), so high-value co-living interactions happen elsewhere and are not captured.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: The product was positioned primarily for matching, and users can manage living arrangements through other channels.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Users feel the platform 'left' at the moment real trust is tested, which lowers emotional attachment and removes the opportunity to convert lived behavior into reusable confidence signals.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, network quality must be sustained with product mechanisms)
evidence.observation: A network does not compound if quality systems do not evolve with usage.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Ignoring the in-stay phase prevents quality compounding from real behavior.

evidence.source: Roomi competitor UX observation from Layer 0 active_stay
evidence.observation: Core surface focuses on pre-match and matching, not post-move operations.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Lifecycle value is truncated before trust data can mature.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: even lightweight co-living tools would feel surprising because users currently expect total handoff after matching.

disappointments.title: No Portable Reputation After the Stay
disappointments.what_happens_now: After a roommate arrangement ends, users have limited structured ways to leave nuanced, portable reputation that improves future matching confidence across neighborhoods or cities.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Users can still return and search again; lack of post-stay depth does not break immediate flows.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: People feel prior good behavior is not rewarded, so each new search carries near-first-time uncertainty; this reduces trust carryover and suppresses network compounding.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, maintaining network quality and carrying capacity)
evidence.observation: As networks scale, quality controls are required to avoid degradation.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Post-stay reputation is a core quality-control mechanism for trust-sensitive markets.

evidence.source: Roomi competitor UX observation from Layer 0 post_stay
evidence.observation: Post-tenancy feedback and reusable trust loops are limited.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The network repeatedly resets trust instead of accumulating it.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: a respected, portable roommate reputation would feel like a step-change in confidence where users currently expect zero long-term credit.

disappointments.title: Returners Re-Enter a Lukewarm Network
disappointments.what_happens_now: Users typically return only during lease transitions, and the product offers limited between-event value, so they come back cold and must rebuild context, trust, and outreach behavior each cycle.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Event-driven usage is normal in housing; the app still supports periodic searches.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Repeated re-onboarding creates learned friction, making users less likely to deepen identity or invite others; local network activity can dip below tipping thresholds between seasonal spikes.

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt (Part I, collapse risk below activity thresholds)
evidence.observation: Networks can unwind when active participation falls below critical density.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Episodic engagement without warm-state mechanisms recreates mini cold starts.

evidence.source: Industry pattern in roommate search cycles
evidence.observation: Usage spikes around relocations and lease turnover, then drops sharply.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Periodic demand without continuity features limits compounding network effects.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: Yes: making off-season participation valuable would surprise users because they expect roommate platforms to be disposable between moves.

disappointment_clusters.pattern: Roomi communicates global activity but not submarket matchability, so users repeatedly infer whether their atomic network is actually above threshold.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: Build explicit neighborhood-time liquidity and response-forecast primitives that make local network health legible before and during search.

disappointment_clusters.pattern: The product supports contact but under-structures trust formation when money, timing, and co-living risk become concrete.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: Own the trust-critical path with structured negotiation, response choreography, and confidence signals that convert matches into reliable agreements.

disappointment_clusters.pattern: Post-match and post-stay behavior is mostly uncaptured, so the network cannot accumulate durable reputation capital.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: Extend into active-stay and post-stay loops to transform one-off matches into a defensible trust graph.
